The Act titled "Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000" establishes federal jurisdiction for certain criminal offenses committed outside the United States under a new chapter 212 in Title 18 of the United States Code. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 establishes federal jurisdiction for criminal offenses committed outside the United States by certain members of the Armed Forces or persons employed by or accompanying them. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 grants federal jurisdiction for criminal offenses committed outside the US by Armed Forces members or accompanying personnel. Prosecution is prohibited if a foreign government is already prosecuting the individual, except with approval from the Attorney General. Military tribunals also have concurrent jurisdiction over offenders and offenses. The Act allows for the arrest and delivery of individuals to the US for judicial proceedings if there is probable cause to believe they violated the Act. Additionally, individuals can be delivered to foreign authorities if requested and if they are alleged to have violated the Act. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows for the delivery of individuals to foreign countries for trial if requested by appropriate authorities and authorized by international agreements. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State, determines the officials considered appropriate authorities. Arrested individuals under the Act shall not be removed to the US or any foreign country, except as specified. Federal magistrate judges can order a person to be removed to the United States, or the Secretary of Defense can waive limitations for military necessity, in which case the person will be taken to the nearest US military installation outside the country for detention and initial proceedings. The Federal magistrate judge conducts initial appearances for individuals under the Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 to determine probable cause for offenses and conditions of release before trial. Detention hearings are also conducted by a Federal magistrate judge for individuals described in the Act. The Federal magistrate judge conducts initial appearances for individuals under the Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000, which may be conducted by telephony or other means enabling voice communication. Regulations govern the apprehension, detention, delivery, and removal of persons under this chapter. The regulations must be uniform throughout the Department of Defense and provide notice to individuals employed by or accompanying the Armed Forces. Sec. 3266 outlines regulations for the apprehension, detention, delivery, and removal of individuals under this chapter, ensuring uniformity throughout the Department of Defense. Sec. 3267 provides definitions for terms used in this chapter and specifies that regulations must be submitted to the appropriate congressional committees before taking effect. ``Sec. 3267. Definitions
    Defines terms related to employment and presence outside the United States by civilian employees, contractors, and dependents of the Armed Forces. The term "United States" refers to dependents of members of the Armed Forces, civilian employees of the Department of Defense, and Department of Defense contractors residing outside the United States, who are not nationals or residents of the host nation. The term "Armed Forces" is defined in section 101(a)(4) of title 10. The terms "Judge Advocate General" and "judge advocate" are defined in section 801 of title 10. A clerical amendment is made to the table of chapters for part II of title 18, United States Code. Military extraterritorial jurisdiction is covered in section 3261 of the United States Code.
